Hello,

I'm new to JUnit and this group. However I read some articles on 
JUnit in general and some of the discussions about the order of 
tests. The common conclusions and recommendations are:
- Avoid dependencies between tests
- If dependencies are necessary however, group these tests in a 
single test case and use a suite method to force the order of 
execution
- The execution order of tests in a suite is in fact the order tests 
were added, although this behaviour results from an implementation 
detail, not from JUnit's specification.

However the following situation might be quite common, especially in 
database environments:
- To test a special function of a class, a large set of (persistent?)
objects must be created, which takes substantial time
- Some test case X needs a SetUp that is exactly the same as the 
result of another test case Y's setUp plus some or all of Y's test 
methods
- There is no possibility of redesigning the application code because 
the classes in test are partially "legacy code", strongly interwoven 
and not heavily tested - this is why we need to write a new test 
suite for them...

The discussions do not provide a solution or recommendation for this.
So to me in this environment the best solution seems to be to let 
one test case Y use a backup of the database that was taken after the 
other test X has (successfully!) run.
Having each test build the complex initialization (even if refactored 
into some initialization classes) is bad because it makes the tests 
run too long - it is diffcult enough to get some developers write and 
use tests, but if they always wait 10 minutes for a test to complete, 
they will not use it a second time...
The backup and restore method might have the advantage that restoring 
the database to that state the developer' test needs is quite fast, 
so that the code-test-improve-test cycle might become less annoying 
to the developer.
I am thinking of implementing a framework (as an extension to JUnit) 
that allows a test case X to define a prerequisite test case Y by 
name. If a backup exists for Y (that is: Y was already run 
successfully before) the backup gets restored and X may quickly 
execute. If no backup exists, first Y gets run, a backup is taken and 
then X is run (and maybe a backup is taken again).
Moreover to minimize the run time of a complete test suite of the 
whole system, even the database could be reused without the need to 
delete and recreate it after each single test run.

Is this idea bad only because it hurts JUnit's ideology, is it bad 
because a solution already exists (where??), is it bad for other 
reasons or is it even a good idea :-) ?

Waiting for your comments,
Uwe Schuster,
Healy Hudson AG
http://www.healy-hudson.com/
